Dear Mr. Lheureux:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
01/16/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Cathrine Raftery, Licensing Consultant

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
3

Maltreatment in Care
There was 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. This was within special investigation 2023C0000256 dated 04/03/2023
which found the facility in non-compliance of staffing not following the agency policy
as it pertains to staff supervision and safety checks. A corrective action plan dated
04/18/2023 was approved that included the staff member involved being terminated
from employment and implentation of training and checklist for staff.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility had ten special investigations during this period under review with two
resulting in a corrective action plan. The non compliances were due to staff not
following the internal policies at the facility. The facility's corrective action plan is
monitored quarterly. The facility has been in compliance with meeting the
expectations of the set deadlines of action steps within their corrective action plans.
The facility's correction plan for their 2023 Renewal report has been fully
implemented. Even though there is a repeat rule violation the facility had found that
error prior to this audit . The facility has been in compliance with having the youth
signatures on the treatment plans.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility’s
budget and the agency’s financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
No Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator reports the staffing has been relatively stable. It is reported,
"coverage for staff on the floor has improved significantly over the last reporting
period. There has been a drastic increase in new hires to back fill staff openings."
Over this reporting period there has been an addition of a case manager to the
license to help with the assistance of the clinician. The Chief Administrator reports,
"this model has improved clinician satisfaction and workload balance, allowing
personal attention to be placed where it is needed. It has improved documentation
compliances and quality of case management care." Over the next year the facility
will continue to focus on recruitment, retention and training of staff. Chief
Administrator reports, "In the upcoming year there will remain a continued
emphasis on both the Directors and Program Managers presence in the units, team
meetings and leadership, as well as focus on coaching and developing therapists
and home supervisors. While the new clinical model has had some success and
some tangible strengths, there also remain growing pains within the relationship of
team leadership."
4

Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were conducted during the inspection and no issues or concerns
were raised. The staff reported feeling supported by direct supervisors as well as
administration. The staff reported they feel the trainings they have received are
beneficial and have had a positive impact on the youth.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection and all youth reported
feeling safe at the facility. The youth all reported they feel the staff are very
supportive to them and treat them with kindness. Each youth reported having a
positive relationship with at least one staff member on their unit who they can talk
to if they have any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on January 16, 2024.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
